Differentiating a quotient

In this Section we consider functions of the form \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\). To find the derivative of such a function we make use of the following Key Point:

Key Point

Quotient Rule

If \(y = \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}\), then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ g(x) \dfrac{df}{dx} - \dfrac{dg}{dx}f(x)}{[g(x)]^2}\] or \(y' = \dfrac{ gf' - g'f}{g^2}\).

In slightly more compact notation we have that if \(y = \dfrac{u}{v}\), then \[ \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{ v \dfrac{du}{dx} - \dfrac{dv}{dx}u}{v^2}\] or \(y' = \dfrac{ vu' - v'u}{v^2}\). 

These are two equivalent versions of the quotient rule.


Example

Find the derivative of \(y = \dfrac{\ln x}{x}\).

Solution

Here \(f(x) = \ln x\) and \(g(x) = x\)

\[ \therefore \dfrac{df}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{x} \text{ and } \dfrac{dg}{dx} = 1 \] Hence \(\dfrac{dy}{dx} =\dfrac{x \left( \dfrac{1}{x} \right) - 1(\ln x) }{[x]^2} = \dfrac{1 - \ln x}{x^2}\)

Note that the product rule can also be used to differentiate this function by writing it in the form \(y = f(x)g(x) = (\ln x)(x^{-1})\).
